loans.name: Julie Joy

texts.en: Julie Joy is a married woman who lives in Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by operating a general store and selling livestock supplies. Her husband Emmanuel, who is 43 years old, works as a teacher to earn his living. Julie Joy joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Julie Joy has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her sixth loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 to buy additional stock for the store so that she can continue to save up for future savings and expansion of her business. Julie Joy is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Helina

texts.en: Helina is a married woman who lives in Bataraza, Palawan. She earns her living by operating three businesses: a sari-sari store, food vending and fish vending. Her husband Edno, who is 46 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have six children who are between 6 and 26 years old. Helina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Helina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 11,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her ninth loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000 to buy stock for her sari-sari (general) store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Helina is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en: Rosario is a married woman who lives in Puerto Princesa, Palawan. She earns her living by operating a general store and a buy and sell of dry goods business. Her husband Michael, who is 31 years old, works as a company driver to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are between 3 and 7 years old. Rosario joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2010 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past two loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosario has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her third loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to buy more stock for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future improvement of her business and the education of her children. Rosario is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Saima's Group

texts.en:
Saima belongs to Lahore, which is Pakistan’s second largest city, known for its history and culture. She lives there in the small area named Christian colony with her family in a two-room brick house. She moved here six years ago. She lives in a combined family system with her brother-in-law and mother-in-law. 

Saima is the mother of a daughter and two sons. None of them is able to attend school due to the poor financial conditions of their family.  

Her husband’s name is J. M. and he manufactures cables. He sells his product to different TV cable operators and electronics stores in the city. He is known as an expert in his work and receives a good number of orders every month. Her brother-in-law also works with her husband in his cable manufacturing business while her mother-in-law is a midwife.
 
To support her family financially, Saima operates a small grocery store through which she sells candies, snacks, etc.
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the betterment of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy required materials to  make a larger quantity of cables, which will help him fulfill orders on time and make more profits.
 
Saima is hopeful that a loan investment will put her husband’s business to a better earning position.
 
She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application. She is confident that it will be a good step for her husband’s business growth.

loans.use: To buy materials for cable manufacturing business

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria S. iis 30 years old and married, with three children. Two of them go to school. 

She is currently in the business of selling items like beans. She borrowed a loan to stock more items like beans to sell. 

She hopes to build a concrete house with extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: To stock more items like beans to sell

texts.en: Delba is a married woman who lives in Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:  pig fattening, meat dealing/livestock and farming. Her husband Luis, who is 37 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living. They have two children who are 6 and 11 years old. Delba joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Delba has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,900, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her eighth loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000  to fund her livestock and farming operations and purchase more meat so that she can continue to save up for her children's education and the improvement of her business. Delba is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To fund livestock and farming operations

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is a 44-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a fishing/fish vending business and a rice retailing business.  She lives in the municipality of Narra, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing/fish vending and rice retailing businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,500. Elizabeth is borrowing PHP 18,000 to fund her business operations.  This will be her ninth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Elizabeth aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: To fund her business operations

Her husband Edwin, who is 40 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living. They have two children who are 5 months and 11 years old. Necole joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Necole has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 13, 000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for future house repairs. Necole is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Gladys Wanjiku

texts.en:
Gladys is 27 years old and married to John M..  The couple has two children.  Gladys has farmed in Nduyu Njeru for the last two years.  

She was introduced to Kiva partner KADET, Ltd. by her friend.  This loan will be her fourth.  She has repaid all her previous loans in a timely manner.  She plans to use this loan to buy seeds for planting.  In the future, Gladys hopes to practice large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy seeds for planting

loans.name: Lona

texts.en:
Lona J. is currently in a business of selling biscuits. She is 40 years old, married, with 4 children and 3 of them  go to school. 
J. borrowed a loan to stock more biscuits to sell. She hopes to use the extra profits from her business to pay  her children in  school in the future.

loans.use: Stock more biscuits to sell

loans.name: Merle

texts.en: Merle is a married woman who lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, electronic re-loading and farming. Her husband Leo, who is 41 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living. They have three children who are 6 to 10 years old. Merle joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Merle has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 16,000 helped her earn a monthly income of PHP 30,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her eighth loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to use to buy merchandise to sell in her general store and also to fund her electronic loading business, buying prepaid mobile phone credits wholesale and selling it retail to her neighbors and clients. She is working hard so that she can continue to save up for future house renovation, family needs and her children's education. Merle is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to buy more stocks to sell in the general store and as revolving capital for the electronic load business

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 37 years old and a resident of Nyamira in western Kenya. He is married with two children aged eight and eleven, both of whom attend school. He has worked in mixed farming in Nyamira for nine years.  He produces tomatoes, cabbage, tea, maize, and wheat, all of which he sells locally. He has one farmhand. He mainly depends on the income from his farm to support the basic needs of his family.

James has requested a 45,000Kes loan from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He hopes the income from this loan will improve the his family's living standards and pay for the education of his two children. He intends to buy a pick-up to help transport his produce to the market. Drastic weather conditions and pests remain his major challenges.  He will focus on repaying this loan and then request additional loans.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret has been farming in Nduyu Njeru town for the last 10 years.  She is 42 years old, married to David Kiguru, and they have five children. 
  
She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend.  This will be her fourth loan.  She paid for all her previous loans well and in good time.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy two dairy cows.

In the future, Margaret hopes to become a leading milk producer in Ndunyu Njeru town.

loans.use: To buy two dairy cows.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is aged 23 and a resident of Nyamira town in Western Kenya, where he has been doing mixed farming for four years. His farm produce of milk, beans and maize are sold to the local market. He has employed one farmhand. He gets additional income from his timber business.

Benard has requested a loan of 25,000KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He is focusing on managing the income from this loan to help him start a family and buy more dairy cows. He reckons that heavy rains are the greatest challenge to farming, especially for beans, because they can be destroyed before harvesting.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Wajih

texts.en: Wajih is a 47 year-old married man from Chtoura and owner of a car repair garage since 1999.  He has had 32 years of experience in this field.  Wajih was young when he started working, unlike most of his friends who attended school at that time. Wajih is talented, and he says that he knows every car's cure. He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to improve his business by buying new fuel oils and lubricants necessary to all car types. It's his first time requesting a loan, and he hopes it comes with a good feedback in the future.

loans.use: To buy fuel oils and lubricants

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seedlings.

loans.name: Nabeela's Group

texts.en:
Nabeela is a very supportive lady. She sews clothes for her neighboring clients to share the financial burden with her husband. She is also a very good housewife and performs her household responsibilities very well. She operates her business from her home and receives a good number of orders every month due to the fine quality of her work. 

She lives with her family in a 2-room brick house in Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore is Pakistan’s 2nd largest city, known for its history and culture. She has lived there in the small colony called "Christian colony" for past 9 years. She is the mother of two sons and a daughter. All of them are very young and stay at home. 

Her husband’s name is S. M. and he is a rickshaw driver and drives a rented rickshaw. He provides transport services to school children and to other passengers. 

Nabeela has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to buy his own rickshaw. By purchasing his own rickshaw, he will be able to work for extensive hours and without any time limitations. Nabeela is confident that the loan will help her husband to improve his business condition and increase his monthly profits. 

She is a new loan applicant of Asasah. She is hopeful that it will be a profitable experience for her family.

loans.use: To buy a rickshaw for transportation business

loans.name: Rosmary

Her husband Nelson, who is 46 years old, works as a technician to earn his living. They have five children who are between 10 and 20 years old. Rosmary joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosmary has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 30,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her seventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for her children's education and house repair. Rosmary is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Petronila

texts.en: Petronila is a 62-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  Transportation (Passenger Jeep) and a general store. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Petronila aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Habari Njema Group

texts.fr: Eliza B.  est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe d’affaire Habari Njema, âgée de 48 ans, veuve, mère de 8 enfants qui étudient  tous. Son mari fut décédé suite à une maladie inopinée. La  cliente  Eliza B. est  vendeuse des poissons salés chipsi (le chipsi sont des muettement des poissons salés issus de l’Ouganda-Kampala). Elle installe son point de vente dans un dépôt situé au boulevard Nyamwisi -2 lampes. Elle démarra son activité avec un fonds propre reçu des petites commissions de 20$ dans les quelles elle  intervenait comme un intermédiaire. Il ya 8 ans qu’elle est en activité. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouvelles marchandises (125 Kg de chipsi).  En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise, acheter une parcelle pour sa famille. La cliente Eliza B. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions dédiées aux pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Le groupe Habari Njema est constitué de 26 membres dont 3 clients ne sont visibles sur la photo du groupe..
texts.en:
Eliza B. is an entrepreneur, and president of the Habari Njema business group, which is composed of 26 members, three of whom do not appear in the photo. She is 48 years old, a widow, and the mother of eight children who all attend school. Her husband died from a sudden illness. 

Eliza B. sells “chipsi” (a type of salted fish from Uganda-Kampala). She has a booth with two lamps in a depot located on the Nyamwisi Boulevard. 

She started her business with her own money consisting of small $20 commissions earned as an intermediary. She has been in business for eight years. 

This new loan will allow her to replenish her stock (125 kg of chipsi). She also plans to expand her business and purchase a plot of land for her family. 

Eliza B. wishes to thank Hekima for helping poor women who cannot turn to traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy 125 kg of chipsi

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Serah Njeri

texts.en:
Serah has practised farming in Ndunyu, Njeru town the last 20 years.  She is 62 years old and a widow. Her husband died and she's taking care of their children.  

She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her third loan.  She repaid all her previous loans well and in good time.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy seeds and fertilizer.

In future, Serah hopes to buy more land and practise large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seedlings

loans.name: Janifer

texts.en: Janifer is a 29-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a food market and a rice retailing business.  She lives in the municipality of Rizal, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2010 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food market and rice retailing businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 7,900.  Janifer is borrowing PHP 10,000 to purchase more stocks to sell.  This will be her second loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 5,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Janifer aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Lubna's Group

texts.en:
Lubna has been living in the place called "Christian colony", in the city Lahore for many years with her family, in a 2-room brick house. Lahore is Pakistan’s 2nd largest city, also known for its history and culture. She is 36 years old, married to S. M. and has seven children, three daughters and four sons. Her two elder sons work in a factory and the remaining are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. 

Lubna operates a beauty salon at her home and provides beautician services to her community clients. She is particularly expert in bridal make-up and earns good profits every month from her profession. She is also a very good housewife and performs her household responsibilities very well.  

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her beauty salon business. With the loan, she will buy beauty items such as make-up kits, blush, nail polishes and lipsticks, etc. that will help her offer better quality services to her clients and make more profits. 

Lubna is very confident that her business will make better profits after investing the loan proceeds into it. She has been doing this business for the past seven years. She is a new loan application of Asasah. She hopes that it will be a profitable experience for her.

loans.use: To buy beauty items for beauty salon business

loans.name: Mary Nyambura

texts.en:
Mary has practised farming in Ndunyu, Njeru town for the last five years; she is also a teacher at a local kindergarten.  She is 36 years old, a single mother of two children.  

She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her third loan.  She repaid all her previous loans well and in good time.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy seeds and fertilizer for the next planting season.

In future, Mary hopes to buy more land and practise large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer for the farm

loans.name: Telesfora

texts.en: Telesfora is a widow who lives in Siaton, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating a general store. She has five children who are between 27 and 39 years old. Telesfora joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1991 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Telesfora has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,500, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,000, which she intends to use to purchase more merchandise to sell in her store so that she can continue to save up for future family needs and for business. Telesfora is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise to sell in the general store

loans.name: Jasmin

texts.en: Jasmin is a 42-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: smoked fish, dried fish and fishing. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1997 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 100,000. Jasmin is borrowing PHP 40,000 to purchase fishing gear and equipment. This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 35,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Jasmin aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is currently in the business of selling household products like saucepans. She is 25 years old, married to a businessman, and has no children. Rose took out a loan to stock more household products like saucepans to sell. She hopes to build a house with extra  profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: Stock more household products like saucepans to sell

loans.name: Luvizminda

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing/fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,000. Luvizminda is borrowing PHP 25,000 so that she can purchase fishing gear and equipment. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Luvizminda aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear and equipment

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1998 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing/fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000. Misma is borrowing PHP 20,000 so that she can purchase fishing gear and equipment. This will be her eighth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Misma aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Mary Mwihaki

texts.en:
Mary has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 20 years.  She is 53 years old, married to John M., and they have five children.  

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and this will be her third loan. She paid for her previous loans well and in good time.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy seeds and fertilizer.

In the future, Mary hopes to buy more land and practice large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seedlings.

loans.name: Mary Wanja

texts.en:
Mary W. has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 13 years.  She is 36 years old, married to Joseph Waithaji, and they have three children. 

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend, and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan to buy fertilizer and potato seedlings.

In the future, Mary hopes to buy more land and practice large scale farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and potato seedlings.

loans.name: Julia Nyambura

texts.en:
Julia has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 10 years.  She is 33 years old, married to Joseph Macharia, and they have five children.  

She was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our field officers, and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan to buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm.

In the future, Julia hopes that her farm will grow.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is 50 years old, married to Augustine and has three children. She has been selling fruits and vegetables in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last four years. She was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by one of our field officers and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan to buy more fruits and vegetables for resale. In the future, Lucy hopes to grow her business and move into a more permanent building.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables for resale

loans.name: Elija Kireru

texts.en: Elijah is 37 years old, married to Eunice Njoki and has two children. He has practised farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 11 years.  He was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by one of our field officers and this will be his second loan. He paid back his previous loan well and in good time. He plans to use this loan to buy seeds and fertilizer and pay for labor. In the future, Elijah hopes to buy more land and practise large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer and pay for labor

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is 54 years old, married to a policeman, and has 6 children 4 of them go to school. She is currently in the business of selling soft drinks. Juliana is borrowed a loan to stock more soft drinks to sell. In the future, she hopes to pay her children in school with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: To stock more soft drinks to sell

loans.name: David Njai

texts.en: David is 49 years old and married to Lucy Njeri. He has practised farming in Naivasha town for the last four years. He was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by his friend and this will be his third loan. He has paid all his previous loans well and in good time. He plans to use this loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides for his farm. In the future, David hopes to practise large-scale mixed farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides for his farm

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is 22 and single. For the last three years, he has been selling various products such as rice, sugar, cosmetics and so on. His business is open from 6am until 8pm every day. Emmanuel has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more products for his store. With his profits, he expects to save money for his future and to build his own house.

loans.use: To purchase more products for his store

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar is 26 years old and is married, with two children between 1 and 3 years old. For six years, he has owned a small shop which sells cosmetics, and so on. His business is open from 6.30am until 7pm every day.

Omar has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more products for his business. Omar hopes to earn more profits and to save money for his children’s school fees.

loans.use: To expand his boutique

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn is a married woman who lives in La Castellana, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: selling RTW - ready to wear clothes, a sari-sari store and pig fattening. Her husband Edgar, who is 42 years old, helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 5 mos. and 19 years old. Jocelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jocelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her eighth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to buy more stocks of Ready-to-Wear Clothes  so that she can continue to save up for future business expansion. Jocelyn is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: purchase Ready-to-Wear Merchandise to sell

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en: Letecia is a married woman who lives in Puerto Princesa, Palawan. She earns her living operating a fruit and vegetable vending business .Her husband Teodoro, who is 62 years old, works as an ice cream vendor to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have seven children who are between 9 and 27 years old. Letecia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Letecia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,500 to buy more stock of  fruits and vegetables for trading so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Letecia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en: Clementine is 31 years old and married with two children ages 3 and 5 years old. For 4 years she has been selling Irish potatoes. Her business is open from 7am until 7:30 pm everyday. Clementine has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more Irish potatoes to sell. If this satisfaction is reached, Clementine hopes to earn more profits. With these profits she expects to open her own hair salon.

loans.use: To buy more Irish potatoes

loans.name: Nemesia

texts.en: Nemesia is a married woman who lives in Cebu. She earns her living by weaving abaca. Her husband Alejandro, who is 54 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have four children who are between 18 and 28 years old. Nemesia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nemesia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to buy abaca fiber for weaving and also to pay for other operating expenses so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Nemesia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase abaca fiber for her abaca weaving business

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Mrs. Anita T. is 46 years old and lives in Caputol, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is blessed with seven children. Her husband is a farmer and they own a little parcel of land. Her husband is the one who cultivates the land, and Anita also helps her husband with some of the work, like planting.

She’s thankful to Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for providing them with financial assistance in the past. She is now applying for 50,000 PHP for house renovations.

She has many plans for the future. One of her dreams is to own at least one hectare of coconut land.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For house renovations

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida T. is from the village of San Antonio, Cabisera 18, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 51 years old. Zenaida is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Zenaida owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 25,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Zenaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure

loans.name: Venantie

texts.en:
Venantie is 48 years old and is married, with 3 children between 5 and 16 years old. Venantie has had her restaurant for 6 years and employs 4 people to help her. 

Her business is open from 6am to 10pm every day, except Sunday.  She will use this loan to purchase more food to sell. If she is successful and able to make a profit from the use of her loan, she would like to buy her own house.

loans.use: To expand her restaurant

loans.name: Rhodora

texts.en: Rhodora is 45 years old, single and supports her family by operating three business ventures: pig fattening, gasoline retailing and basket weaving. Rhodora joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past three loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rhodora has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fourth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy livestock supplies for her pigs and gasoline for resale so that she can continue to save up for the future renovation of her house. Rhodora is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase livestock supplies and gasoline for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock more bread and tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Bernarditha

texts.en: Bernarditha is a married woman who lives in Bais City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating a sari-sari (general) store. Her husband Eduardo, who is 57 years old, works abroad as an OFW - overseas filipino worker so that he could save enough to secure his family's future, as well as be able to afford to send his children to college when they grow up. Their  two children who are 9 and 16 years old, are currently going to school. Bernarditha joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she also aspired to do something to improve her family's future wellbeing. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Bernarditha has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,000, which she intends to use to purchase merchandise to sell in her general store so that she can continue to support her family's day to day expenses and her children's school expenses as well as save up for future house renovations and to send her children to school. Bernarditha is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: purchase more merchandise to sell in her general store

loans.name: Charita

texts.en:
Charita F., from the village of Usocan, is 47 years old, married, and has two grown children. To make a living, Charita owns and operates a business making and selling dried foods in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Charita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 16,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used as working capital and to purchase additional inventory. This will be Charita's sixth loan from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As working capital and to purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia lives in Lahore, which is Pakistan’s second largest city and known for its history and culture. She lives there in the area of Yohanabad with her family in a 2 room brick house. She moved there 7 years ago. She is the mother of 3 daughters and 2 sons. All of them stay at home and don’t do anything. Razia is unable to give them an education due to financial constraints. 

Her husband’s name is K. and he is involved in a construction business. Basically, he is a mason by profession and offers his services of construction to builders by constructing homes and buildings. 

Razia operates a clothes sewing business at her home. She is very good at her work and receives regular orders from her neighboring clients. She started this business part time in order to share the financial burden with her family and it has worked well for her since then.  

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the betterment of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy masonry tools, which will help him to complete his work effectively and make extra income. He has been operating this business for the past 10 years and Razia is hopeful that a loan investment will be more profitable for him to earn better profits. 

She is a new loan applicant of Asasah.

loans.use: To buy masonry tools for construction business.

loans.name: Sol

texts.en:
Sol T. is from the village Langatian. He is 48 years old, married, and has 2 school-aged children. He operates a family member's business in the agriculture sector, raising pigs in the backyard. He has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Sol joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Sol is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This will be his 1st loan from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: To purchase feed and vitamins for his pigs.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn A. is from the village of San Antonio, Cabisera 18, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 42 years old. Jocelyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP every harvest season.

In 2011, Jocelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Jocelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita D. is from the village of Dicoyong, part of Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 46 years old. Amelita is married and has 3 children, one is in pre-school, one is in high school, and the other one is in college. She owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector selling a variety of goods. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from the income of her motorcycle transportation services every day. Amelita has been engaged in her business for over 18 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Amelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Amelita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory, working capital, and for motorcycle repair. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Amelita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional stock for her sari-sari store and for motorcycle repair.

loans.name: Lerica

texts.en: Lerica M. has a "sari-sari" (variety store) to generate her daily income. She is 49 and married, living in Ospital, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. Out of five, three of her children are still in school. She joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative to avail herself of its credit facilities & insurances. She availed herself of loans several times already. Now, she has applied for a loan of 50,000 PHP. The money will be used as additional capital for her store. She hopes to replace her present "sari-sari" store with a concrete one and she also plans to save for the education of her children.

loans.use: To purchase additional capital.

loans.name: Gaspar

texts.en:
Gaspar B. is from the village of La Esperanza, Rizal, Zamboanga del Norte. He is 37 years old. Gaspar is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Gaspar engaged in the agriculture sector, planting assorted crops to sell. Gaspar has been engaged in this activity for three years earning a monthly income of 4,000 PHP.

In 2006, Gaspar joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gaspar has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Gaspar is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Gaspar from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business for educational purposes.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Odile

texts.en:
Odile is 21 years old and is single. She sells various goods such as: avocados, soap, sugar, pens, rice, etc. and runs a well-organized and well-known store, which she has had for one year. Her store is open from 7am to 9pm every day and she currently employs one person to help her. 

Odile will use this loan to expand her store. She will use any profits she makes to reinvest in her business and hopes to become financially stable.

loans.use: To expand her small store

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
"Responsible woman" describes Mrs. Judith Laurie, 28 years old, who is married and resides at Clarin Settlement, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She has 3 children. Her eldest child is six years old and youngest is one year old. She got married at an early age but she never regretted it because she is contented and happy with her family.

The need to have an additional source of income aside from that of her husband, inspired Judith to join Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative to request start-up working capital for her auto-load business. Nowadays, electronic load and cell phones are quite in demand both for youth and adults. Now, she is applying for a loan of PHP 6,000 to buy electronic load and some goods for sari-sari store business. She hopes that her business will continue throughout the years despite the business challenges.

loans.use: to buy electronic load & goods for sari-sari store business

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en: Marcelina is currently in the business of selling retail goods like soap. She is 30 years old, married to a doctor, with 3 children. Two of them go to school. Marcelina borrowed a loan to stock more retail goods like soap to sell. She hopes to build a house and pay for her children in school with the extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: To stock more retail goods such as soap to sell.

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia T. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 40 years old. Letecia is widowed and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Letecia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Letecia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Letecia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Letecia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Letecia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 12th loan taken out by Letecia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Mariées toutes dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 36 ans et 5 enfants, les six membres du groupe Benkadi habitent à Pelengana, chef lieu d’une commune rurale dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers leurs activités génératrices de revenus au marché de Pelengana. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de condiments (choux pommés, échalotes et pâtes alimentaires), préparation et vente de jus locaux, calebasses et charbon de bois. 
Dans le besoin d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont adhéré au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 8ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Mah Traoré a une grande réputation à Pelengana pour sa vente de calebasses de tous calibres. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée par les jeunes mariées pour constituer leur trousseau de mariage. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 4 colis de calebasses en gros à la foire de Tonna. La revente se fait au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, en ambulant et au marché de Pelengana, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Madame Mah Traoré espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge certains besoins du foyer. 
Elle a pour objectif de devenir grossiste dans cette activité à travers ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The six members of the Benkadi group, all married women living in monogamous families, are on the overage 36 years old, with five children.  The group members live in Plenegana, the central locality of a rural community in the Ségou Region (the fourth administrative region of Mali).

They know each other through working as vendors at the Pelengana markets. The group members retail condiments (cabbage, potatoes, shallots and pasta),  self-made juice of local fruits, gourds and charcoal. In order to increase their working capital, the group members have decided to joint the Soro Yiriwaso credit program and are now on their 8th solidarity loan.

Mrs. Mah Traoré is well-known in Pelengana as a vendor of gourds of all sizes.  She is very much sought after by brides-to-be putting together their wedding trousseaux.She plans to use her loan to purchase four packages of gourds, wholesale, at the Tonna market. She resells her goods for cash and on credit, out of her home, as an ambulant vendor and at the Pelengana market, to a customer base composed of women and men.
With this loan, Mrs. Mah Traoré hopes to achieve an average monthly income of 22,000 West African Francs, which will be used to pay for some  household needs, with the rest reinvested in her business. Her goal is to become a wholesaler in this field, thanks to the collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: To purchase gourds

loans.name: Cerela

texts.en:
Cerela P. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 51 years old. Cerela is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Cerela owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling wild-caught fish in the local community. Cerela has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Cerela joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cerela has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. Cerela is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Cerela from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Benito

texts.en:
Mr. Benito F., 61 years old, is married and lives in Burgos, Oroquieta City. His source of income comes from a sari-sari (general store) business. His wife is very supportive of him; in fact, she's the one who oversees the business from time to time. 

The business started when Benito became a member of Paglaum Multi-purpose Cooperative. Financial Assistance was provided by the cooperative. He has obtained loans several times already.

Today, Benito applies for PHP 14,900 to buy additional working capital for his sari-sari store business. In the future, the couple dreams of having a mini grocery someday.

loans.use: To buy additional working capital.

loans.name: Emerita

texts.en:
Mrs. Emerita E., 65, is widow and lives in Buenavista, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is a single parent with two children. She has experienced difficulty being a single parent, but it's not a hindrance for her to move on. She found ways to survive, and opened a “sari-sari” (general store) with a loan from Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC). Aside from sari-sari store, she is also engaged in coconut buy and sell, where she earns PHP 800/week.

Emerita was able to manage the business successfully; in fact, it covers her daily consumption needs and also her child's allowance. Now, she is applying for a loan of PHP 14,900 to buy additional goods for her sari-sari store. She will be happy if she sees her child finish school.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Sabali sont mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 33 ans et 3 enfants par femme. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Darsalam de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers leurs activités génératrices de revenus au marché Château de Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente des légumes (choux pommés et échalotes), des articles divers (boîtes d’allumette, colorants, bonbon, thé, …), des habits pour enfants et de la friperie. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce et de se ravitailler au comptant, les membres du groupe ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 10ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Hawa Diabaté compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 20 sacs de choux pommés et 500 kg d’échalotes. Elle se ravitaille en gros avec les foraines des villages environnants de Ségou, au marché Médine de Ségou. La revente se fait en détails au comptant et à crédit, à domicile et au marché Château, à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Madame Hawa   Diabaté espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les petits besoins du foyer au quotidien. 
Elle a pour objectif d’augmenter le volume de son activité dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The four women in the Sabali group are married and are on average 33 years old with 3 children.  Most of them live in monogamous families. They all live in the Darsalam district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali) and became acquainted through their businesses in Segou's Château market.
Group members buy and sell vegetables (round cabbages and shallots), sundries (matchboxes, dyes, candy, tea, ...), children’s and used clothing.   In order to increase their working capital and to have cash for getting fresh supplies, the group members partnered with Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 10th solidarity loan.  Mrs. Hawa Diabaté plans to use her loan to buy 20 sacks of cabbages and 500 kg of shallots. She gets her supplies wholesale from stallkeepers in the villages surrounding Ségou and at Segou's Médine market. She sells her goods retail for cash and on credit, from her home and at the Château market, to a clientele composed mainly of women.  With this loan, Mrs. Diabaté hopes to make an average monthly profit of 30,000 CFA which will be used to reinvest in the business and to take care of small everyday household expenses.  Her goal is to increase the volume of her business in partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: To buy vegetables (round cabbages and shallots)

loans.name: Kiran's Group

texts.en:
Kiran lives in a historic city of Pakistan called Lahore. Lahore is the second largest city of Pakistan and is also known for its history, gardens, culture and food. She has lived there with her family in the area of Yohanabad for the past 5 years.

She is 29 years old and is married to A., who is a driver by profession and provides transport services to passengers. She has given birth to 2 daughters. Her elder daughter is in class one while the other is only 1 and half years old. 

Kiran is a very supportive lady. In order to share the financial burden with her husband, she runs a beauty salon at her home. She is expert in her work and famous for her bridal makeup skills. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to further improve her beauty salon business. With the loan, she will buy cosmetics and other beauty products like facial creams etc. to provide quality services to her clients.

She is very confident that it will bring maximum profits to her in future. She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and hopes that it will bring positive changes to her business.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and beauty products for beauty salon business.

loans.name: Luciana Wanjala

texts.en:
Luciana M., aged 35, runs a poultry business in Dandora. She is married to Eliud Mwarua, aged 44, who works in the Ministry of Public Works and together they have four children:  Michael, Terry, Margaret and Jane who are fourteen, twelve, seven and three years old respectively. She was introduced to KADET LTD by an existing customer.

She has been in this business for one year and she intends to use the loan of KES. 90,000 to buy more chickens to raise for egg production. She earns a monthly profit of KES. 10,000.

Dandora is a well-populated area hosting people of medium class who provide a ready market for Luciana’s business. If the loan boosts her business she will supply chicken and chicken products to big hotels. Luciana describes herself as a hardworking person who is focused.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens for egg production.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn V., a 43 year old married woman with three school-aged children, is from the city of Dipolog where she owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling different kinds of products to the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Evelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional stock. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock.

loans.name: Saniya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Saniya sont mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec une moyenne d’âge de 48 ans et 5 enfants par femme. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Darsalam de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de leurs activités de petit commerce dans le marché Château de Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente de pâtes alimentaires, de bananes,   de pagnes wax et bazins. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce et de se ravitailler au comptant, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 6ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
 Madame Ba Kadia Samaké, qui est la présidente du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter une tonne (1000kg) de banane en gros avec les maraîchers de Koutiala au grand marché de Ségou. La revente se fait en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à domicile et au marché Château à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Madame Ba  Kadia  Samaké espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les petits besoins du foyer au quotidien. 
Elle a pour objectif à l’image des autres femmes du groupe d’augmenter le volume de son activité dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The four women in the Saniya group are married living mostly in monogomous families. On average they are 48 years old with 5 children each. They all live in the Darsalam neighborhood of Ségou (4th Administrative District of Mali) and met through family connections and through trading at the Château Market in Ségou. 

The members of the group buy and sell pasta, bananas, wax "pagnes" (colorful African cloth) and damask cloth. With the goal of increasing their working capital and to pay cash for their supplies, they decided to work with Soro Yiriwaso and are on their sixth group loan cycle.

Mrs. Ba Kadia Samaké, president of the group, plans to use her loan to buy a tonne (1,000 kg) of bananas wholesale from the Koutiala growers at the  Ségou Market. She then sells the bananas at retail, for cash and on credit, at home and at the Château  Market, to customers who are both men and women. With this loan, Mrs. Ba Kadia Samaké hopes to make an average monthly  profit of 25,000 CFA francs which will be used to re-invest in the business and to pay for small daily household expenses. Along with the other women in the group, her goal is to increase her level of activity thanks to this collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: To buy bananas

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Mrs. Nenita G. lives in San Vicente Bajo, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old, married, and has three children who are all in school. Her husband is a fisherman, and his catch is sold to neighbors.

In April, 2008 she became a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative and has received several loans. Some of these loans were used for gasoline and fishing nets. Now, she is requesting a loan to buy a variety of fish for sale. She would be happy if all of her children finish their studies.

loans.use: To buy a variety of fish.

loans.name: Tété

texts.fr: Monsieur Tété habite quartier Adidogomé. Il est marié et père de  2 enfants. Il  est âgé de 62 ans. Il exerce comme activité la vente de carte de recharge et téléphone. Il  a commencé  en 2006 et s’approvisionne à la direction Togocel, Togo Telecom et Moov. Ensuite il revend dans une cabine à côté de Boukarou.   Il demande un crédit  pour  acheter  200 cartes Togocel, 80 cartes Illico Togo télécom et 150 cartes Moov.
texts.en: Monsieur Tété lives in the Adidogomé area. He is a married father of two. He is 62 years old. He makes his living by selling phone cards and phones. He started in 2006 and stocks up with Togocel, Togo Télécom and Moov. He then sells in a booth next to Boukarou. He is seeking a loan to buy 200 Togocel cards, 80 Togo Télécom cards, and 150 Moov cards.

loans.use: to buy phone cards

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en:
Cecelia B. is from the village of New Look. She is 48 years old. Cecelia is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Cecelia owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Cecelia has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Cecelia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Cecelia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 15th loan taken out by Cecelia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen is a very supportive lady. She runs a grocery store at her home and sells daily use items to her community clients. She is also a very good housewife and does her household responsibilities effectively. She has very good administrative abilities and runs the expenses of her home very well.
 
She lives with her family in a three room brick house in Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore is Pakistan’s 2nd largest city and known for its history and culture. She has been living there in the area of Yohanabad for the past 15 years. She is the mother of 4 sons and a daughter. She knows the importance of education very well and that’s why she has enrolled four of her children at a local school and they are getting their education. Her eldest son didn’t show interest in education and started working in a factory. Her husband’s name is Y. M. and he works in a government organization on a meager income.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her grocery store business. With the loan, she will buy groceries like spices, sugar, lentils, cooking oil, etc. in bulk quantity to sell.  She started this business 2 years ago and hopes that the loan investment will bring more profits. She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and hopes that it will bring positive financial results for her business.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery store business.

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is 28 years old and she is married with three children aged between 2 and 9 years old. Marie’s husband is a businessman, and they do the same business. Marie owns a business selling mobile phones.

Marie has now requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of increasing her business by purchasing various styles of mobile phones to attract more customers. The increased business will help her to earn more profits, which will allow her to resolve the problems she has.

loans.use: To buy more mobile phones to sell.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna A. is from the village of Banonong. She is 35 years old and married with 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna operates a fish pond, raising fish, crab, and prawns. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Myrna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from PMPC. Myrna is now requesting a 8,000 PHP loan which will be used to purchase fries and fingerlings for her business. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Myrna from PMPC.

loans.use: To purchase fries and fingerlings for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 34-year-old engaged man from Lebanon. He is living with his parents and one sibling.  He has been working as a building painter for 16 years sticking with multiple construction projects. In 2006, he decided to continue his operation on a freelance basis depending on customers’ demand. From time to time, he employs part-time workers to help him achieve the tasks. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase additional tools and equipment.  He is very optimistic and willing to increase his profit so he can save money for his wedding. In the future, he hopes to expand his business operation, open his own painting shop, and hire full-time employees.

loans.use: to purchase additional tools and equipment

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a 40 year old farmer. He has been engaged in dairy farming for over ten years. He also does poultry farming to earn extra income. Being a married man with three children in school, he works hard in his business to provide for his family.

David joined Faulu Kenya after he was introduced by his friend. Since then, he has been able to improve his business and his living standard. He has requested a loan of 70,000 Kes to buy a dairy cow.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a 24 year old farmer.  He is married and blessed with a three year old child. He does dairy farming to earn a living, which he started five years ago. He joined Faulu Kenya so that he could access financial resources easily. Hence, he has grown his business with his previous loans from Faulu Kenya. He has requested another loan of 70,000 Kes to buy a dairy cow, set up a cow shed, and pay his laborers.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow, set up a cow shed, and pay his laborers.

loans.name: Joseph Njoroge

texts.en:
Joseph Njoroge K. buys and sells firewood in Limuru town. He has been in this business for the last seven years, and earns an income of KES. 40,000 per month. He 27 years old, married to Ruth, and they have one child.  

He has never borrowed from any other MFI, and he learned about KADET from a member of a group registered with KADET. He is applying for a third loan from KADET LTD, which he plans to use to buy a power saw for cutting firewood.        

Joseph intends to save the anticipated profits to set up a business premise and provide the best living standard for his family.

loans.use: To buy a power saw for cutting firewood.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 48 years old and she is married with four children between 18 and 25 years old. Christine owns a business selling Irish potatoes. Her business is open from 8 am to 6 pm. She has seven years of experience in this business and Christine works every day each week except on the weekend.

Christine has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of increasing her business by purchasing more Irish potatoes to sell. The increased business will help her to earn more profits which will allow her to be more stable financially.

loans.use: To buy more Irish potatoes to sell.

loans.name: Pilista

texts.en: K. is currently in business selling charcoal. She is 47 years old, a widow with seven children and five of them go to school. K. borrowed a loan to stock more charcoal to sell. She hopes to build a house with extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: Stock more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Indira

texts.en: Indira is currently in business selling charcoal. She is 32 years old, married to a policeman, with four children and all of them go to school. Indira borrowed a loan to stock more charcoal to sell. She hopes to build a house with extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: Stock more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Alice Kemunto

texts.en:
Alice Kemunto is married to Nahashon Omenge. She has been operating a beauty salon for three years and earns a monthly income of ten thousand shillings.

Alice was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend. She has serviced her fourth loan well and will use the current loan to add cosmetics for her salon.

She will use the extra profit to open another salon. She has a dream of owning a big beauty parlor. She describes herself as a very hard-working lady.

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics for the salon

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old married man living with his wife and two children who are attending school. He is from Lebanon. He has been working in the construction field for 7 years. He is specialized in painting buildings. In 2006, he started to work independently according to clients' request. He also works with multiple construction projects. In parallel, he works as a maintenance agent in a local company. He works hard in both jobs to be able to meet the family's financial needs. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l so he can buy a car. In that way, he will be able to make his transportation faster and much easier. This will result in increasing his productivity and thus his income.  In the future, he is planning to work on bigger projects and build a good business reputation.

loans.use: buy a car

loans.name: Esther Wachuka

texts.en:
Esther K., aged 49, runs a quarry business in Lukenya. She is a proud mother of three children; Benson, 30 years old, a working class person; Ann 22 years old, a college student; and Margaret, 18 years old, a form four student. Esther was introduced to KADET LTD by an existing client.

Esther has operated this business for 22 years and it generates a monthly profit of KES. 19,500. With this loan, she will purchase another quarry  site. If the loan boosts the business, she will use the extra profits to buy a lorry for the transportation of stones to customers.

In future she wants to have acres of quarry and many lorries for supplying stones to her customers. She describes herself as an ambitious and hard-working lady.

loans.use: Purchase another quarry site

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia is currently in business selling tea. She is 25 years old, married to a soldier, with five children and four of them go to school. Lucia borrowed a loan to stock more tea to sell. She hopes to build a house with extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: Stock more tea to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She lives with her husband and her newborn baby. She started her business as a beautician from her home. She has been involved in this occupation since 2004. Her business is essential because with its income, she is able to help her husband pay the household expenses. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to invest in expanding her inventory selection. She has high hopes for the future of her business; she is looking to continue expansion of her business in the coming year and open a formal beauty salon.

loans.use: invest in expanding her inventory selection

loans.name: Hallen

texts.en: J. is currently in business selling ice cream. She is 30 years old, married to a businessman, with five children and three of them go to school.  J. borrowed a loan to stock more ice cream to sell. She hopes to  build a house with extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: Stock more ice cream to sell

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine is 46 years old and she is married, with four children between 14 and 25 years old. Christine owns a business selling fish. Her business is open from 8am to 6pm. She has an experience of six years in this business and she works every day in the week. Christine has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of increasing her business inventory by purchasing more fish to sell. The increased business will help her to earn more profits which will allow her to become stable financially.
